bibl.title: English translation [from Spanish] of letter from Ignacio Alvare to Philip Showalter Hench, December 8, 1941

div1.p: This is a full translation of Alvare's letter, in which he praises Hench for his attempt to give Finlay credit for his yellow fever work. He describes his visit with former interns from the Hospital Militar and their recollection of Camp Lazear. He explains the origin of the photograph that he recently sent Hench, identifying the photographer as Felipe Ortolazabal.

div1.head: English translation [from Spanish] of letter from Ignacio Alvare to Philip Showalter Hench, December 8, 1941 See Spanish original.
div1.p:
Yesterday I wrote to you acknowledging receipt of your kind letter of
November 26. I congratulate you because you propose to undertake a campaign to
give to Dr. Finlay and the members of the American Investigating Commission the
honor that their theory deserves. In honor to the historical truth one cannot
speak of yellow fever and its conquest without ennobling the glorious figure of
our wise one who, fighting against the indifference of the epoch and the disbelief
of all, had the satisfaction of seeing proved to the last end, his magnificent
theory by a group of honorable scientific men. If you attain to make this truth
come out you will realize a work worthy of all praise and you will have the appre-
ciation of all of us Cubans who feel the glories of our country.

Yesterday I went to Santiago de las Vegas and saw Dr. Marrero, Jr.
who was an interne at the Hospital Militar in my time, and resided there a long
time. Between us we are to make more concrete the information that interests you.
Yesterday also, Dr. Arturo Sansores accompanied me, who was a physician of the
hospital, and Dr. Ricardo Repilado, present Chief of Municipal Sanitation of Havana
and who was a very good friend of ours. This morning at 10 o'clock we conferred
and in order not to be mistaken, went to the Pavilion of Infectious Illnesses of the
Military Hospital, from whose back terrace I could visualize that little house in my
hours as an interne in that room. In the act of looking at it, I could spot the
tree and there we directed ourselves, and together with Dr. Marrero and Dr. Sansores,
on the ground, we recalled that the little house had faced toward the railroad line.
There is no doubt whatever as to the identity of the tree. The front of the small
building faced toward the north with a slight inclination toward the east, and from
there one finds the railroad line a distance not more than 30 to 35 steps, that is
some 70 feet. I remember perfectly the location of the house when as a student I
strolled around those corners.

I want to clear up a mistaken impression that you have about the photograph
that you seem to interpret was taken by me. The photograph was taken at the time of
my interneship on a day that you already know and I had no security about the person
who had taken it. I believed that it was one of my companions at the hospital but
Dr. Arturo Sansores who has the same thing, informed me this morning that the photo-
graph was taken by Lt. Felipe Ortolazabal and I know that all of us students keep
a veneration for the historical remembrance that is portrayed therein for us. For
that reason I delivered one to another--one of my favorite professors, Dr. Recio. I
want you to realize all this data if mention is made of it in your work so that you will
not think that I want to take credit for something that doesn't belong to me, because
what there is here of worth is the preserved photograph which anyone whatever could
obtain, and I have been no more than the conducting wire through which you have ob-
tained this knowledge. Be sure that the information that I gave you is correct because
I have transported myself there to recall it and after my visit to that place had en-
graved on my mind the view of the little house with its tree and the rest of the details
of the place. I want to congratulate you for your zeal in all this that results so
interesting and above all because your put in his true place of glory our wise Finlay
in a deed that was of such great transcendence for humanity.

closer.seg: P.S. In another envelope I am sending you the photographs and sketches.
